103.01 STATIONERY LETTERHEAD.
   (a)   The Mayor shall choose the official letterhead of the Village.
Stationery incorporating such letterhead shall be used in all official external
communications from all Municipal elected officials, officers, department heads
and employees.
(Ord. 2019-20. Passed 4-10-19.)
   (b)   Individual Village elected officials, officers and department heads
may communicate externally utilizing stationery which only lists their name and
department, provided, however, that the official Village letterhead is still
incorporated in such stationery.
(Ord. 1988-83. Passed 11-23-88.)
103.02 VILLAGE SEAL.
   The seal of the Village of Woodmere, Ohio that hangs in Village Hall is
hereby officially adopted as the official seal of the Village pursuant to Ohio
R.C. 715.01.
(Ord. 1995-114. Passed 12-20-95.)
103.03 VILLAGE LOGO.
   (a)   Council does herein recognize and adopt the logo, as set forth below,
to be the
official logo for the Village of Woodmere:
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/0fa7b24cf4fa265f5a2ec2542c95b0678b8620ba/
IMAGES/0-0-0-3397_6148x3376.jpg]
   (b)    The official logo of the Village shall be and remain the property of
the Village of Woodmere until revised, redesigned and replaced by action of
Council and use thereof is protected copyright.
   (c)    The official logo of the Village shall not be altered, defaced or
used in a degrading manner.
   (d)    The use of the Village logo may be used by Village officials for
public, civic and/or Village purposes of any official nature, and use by or for
any individual, organization
or group for political or personal purposes is expressly forbidden, unlawful
and prohibited.
   (e)   The logo may be used for decals for placement on Village vehicles and
on brochures, schedules, information bulletins, newsletters and other
publications which are created by the Village for use in various Village
programming and the dissemination
of information to Village residents.
   (f)    The official logo shall not be used as a substitute for the Village
seal.
(Ord. 2019-25. Passed 5-8-19.)
CHAPTER 105
Open Meetings
105.01   Definitions.
105.02   Notice of regular and organizational meetings.
105.03   Notice of special meetings.
105.04   Notice to news media of special meetings.
105.05   Notification of discussion of specific types of public business.
105.06   General regulations.
105.07   Public meetings.
105.08   Notice/warning sign to be posted at entrance of Council Chambers or in
Village Hall.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
State references - see Ohio R.C. 121.22
Planning and Zoning Commission - see ADM. Ch.
139
Architectural Review Board - see ADM. Ch.
141
 
105.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For purposes of this chapter the following words and phrases shall have the
following meanings ascribed to them respectively.
   (a)   “Clerk of Council” means the Village Clerk of Council.
   (b)   “Day” means a calendar day.
   (c)   “Meeting” means any prearranged discussion of the public business of
the municipal body by a majority of the members of the municipal body.
   (d)   “Municipal body” means each of the following: Council, Planning and
Zoning Board, Board of Zoning Appeals, Architectural Review Board, and
committees of the above municipal bodies comprised of members of such bodies.
   (e)   “Oral notification” means notification given orally either in person,
by telephone, directly to the person for whom the notification is intended, or
by leaving an oral message for the person at the address, or if by telephone,
at the telephone number of the person as shown on the records kept by the Clerk
of Council under this chapter. (Ord. 1976-06. Passed 4-21-76.)
   (f)    “Post” means to post in an area accessible to the public during the
usual business hours at the office of the Clerk of Council and at the locations
listed below. A notice identifying the locations at which notification will be
posted pursuant to this subsection shall be published by the Clerk of Council
within ten calendar days after its adoption.
      (1)    Digital Information Sign outside the entrance to Village Hall
         27899 Chagrin Boulevard
         Woodmere, Ohio
      (2)    Cuyahoga County Public Library
         31975 Chagrin Boulevard
         Pepper Pike, Ohio
      (3)    Village website – www.woodmerevillage.com
         (Ord. 2022-99. Passed 11-9-22.)
   (g)   “Published” means published once in a newspaper having a general
circulation in the Municipality, as defined in Ohio R.C. 7.12 except that no
portion of the newspaper need be printed in the Municipality. If at the time of
any publication there is no newspaper of general circulation, then the
publication shall be in a newspaper then determined by the Clerk of Council to
have the largest circulation in the Municipality.
   (h)   “Special meeting” means a meeting which is neither a regular meeting
nor an adjournment of a regular, or special, meeting to another time or day to
consider items specifically stated on the original agenda of the regular, or
special, meeting.
   (i)   “Written notification” means notification in writing mailed,
telegraphed, or delivered to the address of the person for whom the
notification is intended as shown on the records kept by the Clerk of Council
under this chapter, or in any way delivered to the person. If mailed, the
notification shall be mailed by first- class mail, deposited in a U.S. Postal
Service mailbox no later than the second day preceding the day of the meeting
to which the notification refers, provided that at least one regular mail
delivery day falls between the day of mailing and the day of the meeting.
(Ord. 1976-06. Passed 4-21-76.)
105.02  NOTICE OF REGULAR AND ORGANIZATIONAL MEETINGS.
   (a)   The Clerk of Council shall post a statement of the time and place of
regular meetings of each municipal body for each calendar year not later than
the second day preceding the day of the first regular meeting, other than the
organizational meeting, of the calendar year of that municipal body. The Clerk
of Council shall check at reasonable intervals to ensure that the statement
remains so posted during the calendar year. If at any time during the calendar
year the time or place or regular meeting is changed on a permanent or
temporary basis, a statement of the time and place of the changed regular
meeting shall be so posted by the Clerk of Council at least twenty-four hours
before the time of the first changed regular meeting.
   (b)   The Clerk of Council shall post a statement of the time and place of
any organizational meeting of a municipal body at least twenty-four hours
before the time of the organizational meeting.
   (c)   Upon the adjournment of any regular or special meeting to any other
day, the Clerk of Council shall promptly post notice of the time and place of
the adjourned meeting.
(Ord. 1976-06. Passed 4-21-76.)
105.03 NOTICE OF SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   (a)   Except in the case of a special meeting referred to in Section
105.04(d), the Clerk of Council shall, no later than twelve hours before the
time of a special meeting of a municipal body, post a statement of the time,
place and purposes of the special meeting.
   (b)   The statement under this section and the notifications under Section
105.04 shall state the specific or general purpose or purposes then known to
the Clerk of Council that are intended to be considered at the special meeting
and may state, as an additional general purpose, that any other business that
may properly come before the municipal body at the meeting may be considered
and acted upon.
(Ord. 1976-06. Passed 4-21-76.)
105.04  NOTICE TO NEWS MEDIA OF SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   (a)   Any news media organization that desires to be given advance
notification of special meetings of a municipal body shall file with the Clerk
of Council a written request therefor. Except in the event of an emergency
requiring immediate official action as referred to in subsection (d) hereof, a
special meeting shall not be held unless at least twenty-four hours advance
notice of the time, place, and purposes of the special meeting is given to the
news media that have requested such advance notification in accordance with
subsection (b) hereof.
   (b)   (1)   News media requests for advance notification of special meetings
shall specify: the municipal body that is the subject of such request; the name
of the media; the name and address of the person to whom written notifications
to the media may be mailed, telegraphed, or delivered; and the names,
addresses, and telephone numbers, including addresses and telephone numbers at
which notification may be given either during or outside of business hours of
at least two persons to either one of whom oral notifications to the media may
be given, and at least one telephone number which the request identifies as
being manned, and which can be called at any hour for the purpose of giving
oral notification to the media.
      (2)   Any such request shall be effective for one year from the date of
filing with the Clerk of Council or until the Clerk of Council receives written
notice from the media canceling or modifying such request, whichever is
earlier. Each requesting news media shall be informed of the period of
effectiveness at the time it files its request. Such request may be modified or
extended only by filing a complete new request with the Clerk of Council. A
request shall not be deemed to be made unless it is complete in all respects,
and the request may be conclusively relied on by the Village, the municipal
body that is the subject of such request, and the Clerk of Council.
   (c)   The Clerk of Council shall give such oral notification or written
notification, or both, as the Clerk of Council determines, to the news media
that have requested such advance notification in accordance with subsection (b)
hereof, of the time, place, and purposes of each special meeting, at least
twenty-four hours prior to the time of the special meeting.
   (d)   In the event of an emergency requiring immediate official action, a
special meeting may be held without giving twenty-four hours advance
notification thereof to the requesting news media. The persons calling the
meeting, or any one or more of such persons or the Clerk of Council on their
behalf, shall immediately give oral notification or written notification, or
both, as the person or persons giving the notification determine, of the time,
place, and requested advance notification in accordance with subsection (b)
hereof. The minutes or the call, or both, of any special meeting shall state
the general nature of the emergency requiring immediate official action.
(Ord. 1976-06. Passed 4-21-76.)
105.05  NOTIFICATION OF DISCUSSION OF SPECIFIC TYPES OF PUBLIC BUSINESS.
   (a)   Any person, upon written request and as provided herein, may obtain
reasonable advance notification of all meetings at which any specific type of
public business is scheduled to be discussed. Such person may file a written
request with the Clerk of Council specifying: the person’s name, and the
address and telephone number at or through which the person can be reached
during the outside of business hours; the specific type of public business the
discussion of which the person is requesting advance notification; the
municipal body that is the subject of the request; and the number of calendar
months, not to exceed twelve, which the request covers. The request may be
canceled by request from the person to the Clerk of Council. Each written
request shall be accompanied by an advance payment of seventy-five dollars
($75.00) per year. A two dollar ($2.00) fee will be deducted from this amount
and a self-addressed envelope shall be required for each notification by mail
of all regular or special meetings requested. A one dollar ($1.00) fee will be
deducted from this amount for each notification by telephone of all regular
and/or special meetings requested. Any unused funds will be returned at the end
of the year. No interest shall be paid on funds on deposit. The request may be
modified or extended only by filing a complete new request with the Clerk of
Council. A request shall not be deemed to be made unless it is complete in all
respects, and the request may be conclusively relied on by the municipal body
that is the subject of the request, and the Clerk of Council.
   (b)   The Clerk of Council shall give such advance notification under this
section by written notification, or by oral notification, or both, as the Clerk
of Council determines. The contents of written notification under this section
may be a copy of the agenda of the meeting. Written notification under this
section may be accomplished by giving advance written notification, by copies
of the agendas, of all meetings of the municipal body that is the subject of
the request.
(Ord. 1976-06. Passed 4-21-76.)
105.06  GENERAL REGULATIONS.
   (a)   Any person may visit or telephone the office of the Clerk of Council
during that office’s regular office hours to determine, based on information
available at that office: the time and place of regular meetings; the time,
place, and purposes of any then known special meetings; and whether the
available agenda of any future meeting states that any specific type of public
business, identified by the person, is to be discussed at the meeting.
   (b)   Any notification provided herein to be given by the Clerk of Council.
   (c)   A reasonable attempt at notification shall constitute notification in
compliance with this chapter.
   (d)   A certificate by the Clerk of Council as to compliance with this
chapter shall be conclusive upon this village and municipal body involved.
(Ord. 1976-06. Passed 4-21-76.)
105.07  PUBLIC MEETINGS.
   (a)    Meetings and hearings of any municipal body, including Council,
Council committees, citizen advisory committees to Council, commissions, boards
and other similar municipal bodies of the Village, may be held, and members may
attend meetings and may conduct and attend hearings of any municipal body, in-
person, and/or by means of video conference, or any other similar electronic
technology (hereinafter collectively referred to in this Section as “electronic
technology”), or any combination of in-person and electronic technology. Each
municipal body may establish rules of conduct for the meetings and hearings of
such municipal body, as long as such rules are in compliance with this section.
   (b)    Any resolution, ordinance, rule, decision or other formal action of
any kind made or taken during any municipal body meeting or hearing conducted
entirely or in-part with members attending, participating, and voting by
electronic technology, shall have the same effect as if it had occurred during
an in-person meeting or hearing of the municipal body.
   (c)    Members of a municipal body who attend meetings or hearings by means
of electronic technology, shall be considered present as if in-person at the
meeting or hearing, shall be permitted to vote, and shall be counted for
purposes of determining whether a quorum is present at the meeting or hearing,
so long as the member attending the meeting or hearing by electronic technology
is visible to the other members and the public.
   (d)    Notice of any meeting or hearing conducted entirely or in-part with
members attending, participating, and voting by electronic technology, shall be
provided as required by Sections
105.02 ,
105.03  and
105.04  of the Codified Ordinances.
   (e)    Public access must be provided to all municipal body meetings or
hearings unless an executive session is expressly authorized by and has been
duly convened under the applicable provisions of the laws of the State of Ohio.
If no in-person access to the public for a particular municipal body meeting is
feasible due to health or safety concerns, or if any member of a municipal body
is permitted to attend, participate and vote at a municipal body meeting or
hearing by electronic technology, then public access shall be provided to the
public by electronic technology during such meeting or hearing.
   (f)    The Village may determine the method of attendance and participation,
if permitted, by the public through electronic technology, and such method need
not be the same as the method of electronic technology used by a member of the
public body to attend, participate and vote at such meeting. The methods of
electronic technology allowing attendance and/or participation by the public
may include, but are not limited to, live-streaming by means of the internet,
local television, cable, or public access channels, or by means of any other
similar electronic technology. When the public is allowed to attend and/or
participate electronically, the municipal body shall ensure that the public can
observe and hear the discussions and deliberations of all the members of the
municipal body, whether the member is participating in person or
electronically.
   (g)    This section does not require that members of the public wishing to
attend an entirely in-person meeting or hearing must be given access by
electronic technology, even if in-person access by the public is limited by
health or safety concerns, or any law or regulation.
   (h)    The authority granted in this section applies notwithstanding any
conflicting provision of the Codified Ordinances. Nothing in this section shall
be construed to negate any other provision of the Codified Ordinances that is
not in conflict with this section.
(Ord. 2021-46. Passed 8-24-21.)
105.08  NOTICE/WARNING SIGN TO BE POSTED AT ENTRANCE OF COUNCIL CHAMBERS OR IN
VILLAGE HALL.
NOTICE
   In order to enter Village Hall you may be asked to either pass through a
metal detector or submit to a search.
WARNING
   Unless otherwise authorized by law, pursuant to the Ohio Revised Code, no
person shall knowingly possess, have under the person’s control, convey, or
attempt to convey, a deadly weapon or dangerous ordnance onto these premises.
R.C. 2923.1212(A). No person shall transport into Village Hall any explosive
device, alcoholic beverage, or illegal drugs. Violators will be prosecuted.
(Ord. 2004-62. Passed 7-21-04.)
CHAPTER 107
Contracts, Grants and Property
107.01   Contract procedures.
107.02   Grants.
107.03   Sale of personal property.
107.04      Authority to accept donations.
 
 
107.01 CONTRACT PROCEDURES.
   (a)    Proper Authorization. No contract, or an amendment or a change order
to a contract, shall be enforceable against the Village unless it has been duly
authorized, as provided for herein, and executed in the name of the Village by
the Mayor and bears the signature of Treasurer of the Village, to the extent
required by the Ohio Revised Code, certifying the availability and
appropriation of funds for the contract or any amendment or change order to the
contract.
 
   (b)    Authorization to Investigate Costs. The Mayor shall have the
authority to investigate costs relative to any proposed public improvement or
any proposed purchase or lease of equipment, supplies, services or materials.
(Ord. 2015-50. Passed 8-12-15.)
   (c)    Authorization for Purchase, Lease, Design, Provision of Services. In
the event the investigation or a good faith estimate by the Mayor indicates
that a proposed project, purchase, lease or provision of services will exceed
two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500), the approval of Council by a motion
and majority vote is necessary to authorize the expenditure of such funds.
(Ord. 2019-63. Passed 11-13-19.)
   (d)    Public Bidding. Except as provided in subsection (e), any contract
which: (i) provides for an expenditure in excess of fifty thousand dollars
($50,000); and, (ii) is for the construction of a public improvement or the
purchase or lease of equipment, supplies or materials, or the provision of a
service to the Village, shall be authorized only upon a motion, adopted by a
majority vote of the members of Council, to award the contract to the lowest
and best bidder after advertising for not less than two nor more than four
consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the Village.
   (e)    Exceptions to Public Bidding. Contracts estimated to exceed fifty
thousand dollars ($50,000) and that meet the following conditions are not
subject to competitive bidding and may be approved by Council, in its
discretion, by motion and a majority vote of its members.
(Ord. 2022-25. Passed 5-11-22.)
      (1)    Personal or Professional Services. Contracts that involve personal
services requiring unique and special skills, as determined by Council in its
discretion, or professional services;
      (2)    Cooperative Programs. Contracts authorized pursuant to the Ohio
Department of Administrative Services Cooperative Purchasing Program, or any
other similar program ("cooperative program"), or goods, materials or equipment
which are available under a cooperative program but are available to the
Village upon equivalent or better conditions and specifications, but at a lower
price than is available, under a cooperative program;
      (3)    Design Build. The proposed purchase is a Design-Build Construction
project. The procurement process shall be based on the needs of the Village and
the nature of the specific project and shall not be required to comply with
Chapter 153 of the Ohio Revised Code. Procedures for procurement shall be
developed by the Engineer and Architect, with approval by the Council. The
Design-Builder shall be required to provide a performance and payment bond in
the same form as that set forth in Section 153.571 of the Ohio Revised Code.
The standard of award for Design-Build projects shall be a "best value"
standard;
      (4)    Construction-Manager-at-Risk. The proposed purchase is a
Construction Manager-at-Risk project. The procurement process shall be based on
the needs of the Village and the nature of the specific project and shall not
be required to comply with Chapter 153 of the Ohio Revised Code. Procedures for
procurement shall be developed by the Engineer and Architect, with approval by
the Council. The Construction Manager-at-Risk shall be required to provide a
performance and payment bond in the same form as that set forth in Section
153.571 of the Ohio Revised Code. The standard of award for Construction
Manager-at-Risk projects shall be a "best value" standard;
      (5)    Single Source. The proposed purchase is for something that, as
determined at the sole discretion of the Council, is only available from a
single source;
      (6)    No Bids/Rejected Bids. If no bids are received after the
advertisements or other solicitations required by this Ordinance, or if all
bids are rejected, the Mayor shall either seek new, competitive bids, or seek
to obtain the goods and/or services for which funds have been appropriated
without re-bidding, whichever is deemed to be in the best interest of the
Village;
      (7)    Used Equipment. The proposed purchase is for used equipment;
      (8)    Utility. The proposed purchase is for utilities such as gas,
water, electricity, or telephone service for which funds have been
appropriated; notwithstanding other provisions of this section, Council shall
authorize such purchases pursuant to an ordinance;
      (9)    Intergovernmental Purchases. The proposed purchase is from or with
another political subdivision, the Ohio State Government, or the United States
Government;
      (10)   Reverse Auction. The proposed purchase is obtained through Reverse
Auction;
      (11)    Best Interest Waiver. Council may, at its sole-discretion, waive
the public bidding requirement if it determines that doing so is in the best
interest of the Village.
   (Ord. 2015-50. Passed 8-12-15.)
   (f)    Real Estate. The Mayor may purchase, sell or lease real property
valued below two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500), provided that a
current appropriation supports any such purchase or lease of real estate and
provided that Council is notified of such purchase, sale or lease at the time
of the next Council meeting. The Council may, by ordinance, provide for the
purchase, sale or lease of real property, valued at or in excess of two
thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500), with or without public bidding, on such
terms and for such value as Council, in the exercise of its discretion, may
deem reasonable and in the best interest of the Village.
(Ord. 2019-63. Passed 11-13-19.)
 
   (g)    Time Between Notice of Public Bidding and Bid Opening. There shall be
no minimum time requirement between the publishing of the notice of public
bidding and the opening of the bids.
 
   (h)    Estimate of Cost. The Village shall disclose the estimated cost of
the project when it determines that doing so is in its best interest.
 
   (i)    Time for Award of Bids. In the notice of public bidding required for
the bid solicitation, the Village shall establish the time limit for awarding a
contract. Submitted bids may not be withdrawn during this period. The Village's
failure to award and execute the contract within this period invalidates the
entire bid proceedings and all bids submitted, unless the time for awarding and
executing the contract is extended by mutual consent of the Village and the
bidder whose bid the Village accepts and with respect to whom the Village
subsequently awards and executes a contract. Such an agreed extension shall not
entitle the contractor to delay costs.
 
   (j)    Withdrawal of Bids. Bidders may withdraw bids pursuant Section 9.31
of the Ohio Revised Code; such a withdrawal shall not modify the Village's
right to award to the next lowest and best bidder.
 
   (k)    Bids in Excess of Estimate. The Village may award contracts
regardless of the value of the bid as compared to the value of the estimated
cost.
 
   (l)    Notice to Proceed. The contractor is not entitled to a notice to
proceed with the work by the Village or its representative upon execution of
the contract. The Village shall either issue the notice to proceed at a time
that it determines is in its best interest, or it shall terminate the contract
for its convenience.
 
   (m)    Retainage. Retainage shall be withheld from payments to the
contractor at the rate set forth in the Owner/Contractor agreement. Retainage
shall not be held in an escrow account. Retainage shall be released at such
times and in such amounts as the Village determines to be equitable.
 
   (n)    General Contractor Permitted. The Village may advertise and award a
single contract for constructing and managing an entire public improvement
project.
 
   (o)    Extension of Bid Opening. The Village may issue an addendum or
addenda modifying the plans and specifications for the project or the time for
the bid opening at any time prior to the bid opening. If an addendum is issued
within forty-eight hours before the bid opening, the bid opening shall be
extended by at least three days.
 
   (p)    Combined Statement of Material and Labor. The Village at its
discretion may accept a combined statement of labor and materials from bidders.
 
   (q)    Bonus and Liquidated Damages for Time. The Village may offer a bonus
for completion of a contract prior to a specified date or may exact liquidated
damages for each day of delay beyond a specified date, or both. The amounts of
the bonus and liquidated damages may be different.
(Ord. 2015-50. Passed 8-12-15.)
 
107.02 GRANTS.
   (a)    All applications for grants which require matching funds shall be
authorized by a majority vote of Council and the completed grant application
shall be provided by the department head making the legislative request.
Council authorization is not required to apply for and accept grants that do
not require matching funds from the Village.
(Ord. 2024-32. Passed 7-10-24.)
 
107.03 SALE OF PERSONAL PROPERTY.
   (a)    Personal property owned by the Village that is determined by the
Mayor, and the Department Head having control of the personal property, to have
an estimated value of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000) or less, and to be no
longer needed for municipal purposes, may be sold or disposed of, without
Council approval, by any of the following methods:
      (1)    By sale by sealed bid to the highest and best bidder, following
notice by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the Village and
posting on the Village website at least ten business days prior to the opening
of bids.
      (2)    By live public auction. Notice of live public action will be by
publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the Village and by posting
on the Village website at least ten business days prior to auction.
      (3)    By internet auction. Notice of internet auction will be by posting
on the Village website at least ten business days prior to commencement of
bidding.
      (4)    By sale to another government entity.
      (5)    By trade-in for credit at the time of the purchase of replacement
property, provided that trade-in value is established separately from the
purchase price of the replacement property, and can be verified to represent
fair market value for the traded property.
      (6)    By sale for scrap value or by discarding, if the property can be
shown to have minimal or no residual market value in its current form.
      (7)    By destruction upon the determination by the Director of Public
Safety that the property must be destroyed for public safety reasons.
      (8)    By donation to an appropriate charitable organization.
 
   (b)    Any Village-owned personal property that has been determined by the
Mayor, and Department Head having control of the personal property, to no
longer be needed for municipal purposes and to have an estimated value of
greater than twenty thousand dollars ($20,000) may be sold or disposed of by
any of the above methods with the prior approval of Council.
 
   (c)    The Treasurer shall record the sale or donation of any property
disposed of pursuant to this Section.
 
   (d)    Any property donated to a charity or sold to another government
entity shall be done so by written agreement, as approved by the Director of
Law, that includes the proper release language and the acceptance of the
property in an "as is" condition.
 
   (e)    If no bid is obtained where required for the sale of personal
property, and the procedures provided herein have been followed, the Mayor may
sell such property at public or private sale for the best price obtainable,
subject to the approval of such sale by Council.
 
   (f)    Notwithstanding the provisions of this Section, Council may, by
ordinance enacted hereafter, adopt a different procedure for the sale of any
particular personal property.
(Ord. 2015-50. Passed 8-12-15.)
107.04 AUTHORITY TO ACCEPT DONATIONS.
   (a)    The Mayor is authorized to accept donations of money and/or personal
property on behalf of the Village, so long as:
      (1)    The donation represents an unconditional gift by the donor; and
      (2)    The donation does not require that the Village provide any
matching funds or property; and
      (3)    The fair market value of the donation does not exceed one thousand
dollars ($1,000).
   (b)    Prior to receiving any such donation of money or personal property
that has value of at least two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) the Mayor shall
submit a report to the Clerk of Council approved as to form and substance by
the Director of Law, which shall state the purpose for which the donation has
been made by the donor, and if the donation is money , the Village fund into
which the donation shall be deposited.
   (c)    For purposes of this section, an “unconditional” gift is one in which
there is no obligation imposed by the donor upon the Village as a condition of
acceptance. A gift shall not be considered “conditional’ if the donor simply
restricts the use of the gift to a particular department or division of the
Village, or, if the gift is money, the fund into which the money shall be
deposited.
(Ord. 2019-27. Passed 5-8-19.)

121.01 SALE OF PERSONAL PROPERTY. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Former Section
121.01 was repealed by Ordinance 2015-50, passed August 12, 2015. See Section
107.03 for relevant provisions.)
121.02 MEETINGS.
   (a)    Regular Meetings. Regular meetings of Council shall be held at 7:00
p.m. on the second Wednesday of the month, unless otherwise ordered by Council.
No member of Council shall be required to wait longer than one-half hour after
the regular time for convening the meeting and after which Council stands
adjourned, unless there is a quorum present and Council is called to order and
proceeds to business.
   (b)    Special Meetings. Special meetings shall be called by the President
of Council, or the Mayor, or the Clerk of Council upon written request of four
(4) members of Council. Written notice of such special meeting shall be served
upon each member of Council electronically, personally, or at his place of
residence at least forty-eight hours before such meeting. Special meetings
shall be all meetings other than regular and those called in an emergency
situation. Notification of all such meetings shall be published and/or posted
in accordance with Section
105.03 .
   Such notice shall state the purpose of the meeting and no other matter shall
be considered except on the approval at that meeting by at least two-thirds of
the members of Council. Village officials requested to attend the special
Council meeting shall also be notified in the above manner.
   (c)    Access to Council Chambers. Members of Council shall have access to
Council Chambers on a twenty-four (24) hour, seven (7) day a week basis.
(Ord. 2021-46. Passed 8-24-21.)
121.03 COST OF SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   (a)   All persons, corporations, firms, or entities having business of such
urgency as to require a special meeting of any public body of the Village the
members of which are compensated per meeting, shall be required to advance the
costs, including clerical expenses, for such special meeting.
   (b)   This section shall not pertain to special meetings called by Council.
(Ord. 1984-29. Passed 3-21-84. )
121.04 EXPENDITURES PURSUANT TO CONTRACT, GIFTS AND GRANTS. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Former Section
121.04  was repealed by Ordinance 2015-50, passed August 12, 2015. See Sections
107.01  and
107.02  for relevant provisions.)
121.05 CLERK RECORDER.
   Council hereby establishes the position of Clerk Recorder to record,
transcribe and prepare minutes of Council proceedings, to see that all
legislation and contracts are promptly executed, and presented to the Clerk of
Council and to work with the Council President and Clerk of Council in
establishing a system for maintaining, storing and otherwise keeping its public
records, including records of the various Village Commissions and
administrative agencies.
(Ord. 1989-63. Passed 7-19-89.)
121.06 ATTENDANCE OF COUNCIL MEMBERS.
   For each absence of a member of Council from a regular or special Council
meeting, unless excused by a vote of four Council members, there shall be
deducted by the Treasurer upon the statement of attendance provided by the
Clerk of Council, a sum equal to one hundred percent (100%) of the monthly
salary of such Council member. Council shall excuse absent members who have
presented a valid reason in advance of the meeting at which the member will be
absent. In cases of unexpected emergencies, it shall be the responsibility of
the member who will be absent to notify the Mayor, Council President, Clerk of
Council, or chairman of the committee upon which the member serves no later
than two (2) hours prior to the start of the meeting in order to be considered
for exclusion by the Council members present. (Ord. 2005-36. Passed 4-20-05.)
121.07 ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT.
   (a)   There is hereby established the position of Administrative Assistant
to Mayor and Council and that person shall be paid such compensation as Council
shall from time to time provide. The Administrative Assistant shall be
appointed by Council and shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor and Council
and shall be governed by the Administrative Code of the Village of Woodmere and
shall perform the following duties:
      (1)   Answer in-coming phone calls on the Village business line during
regular Village Hall hours;
      (2)   Log and distribute in-coming mail;
      (3)   Greet and assist visitors in a courteous and professional manner at
all times;
      (4)   Project a professional image in all dealings with the public;
      (5)   Type correspondence as requested by the Mayor and Council;
      (6)   Assist the Mayor in the daily operations of the Village;
      (7)   Assist Council President and Clerk of Council as necessary in
preparation of Council meetings and work sessions.
      (8)   Maintain calendar of meetings, events, and other activities to be
held at the Village Hall on a monthly basis;
      (9)   Serve as assistant and liaison to Mayor, Council President and
other department heads in reception, log-in and opening of sealed bids for
purchases and service;
      (10)   Perform other duties as requested by the Mayor and Council.
         (Ord. 2012-37. Passed 4-18-12.)
121.08 RULES.
   The Rules of Council as set forth in Ordinance 2005-37, passed April 20,
2005, shall be adopted as the Rules of the Woodmere Village Council.

123.01  MANNER OF PUBLICATION OF ORDINANCES AND RESOLUTIONS.
   (a)    Publication of ordinances and resolutions of Council shall be given
by publishing the number, the title thereof and the date of passage thereof,
once a week for one week in a newspaper of general circulation in the Village,
except that in lieu thereof, any ordinance or resolution may be published in
full when so specified therein.
   (b)    All Municipal statements, orders, proclamations, notices and reports
required by law or by ordinance to be published shall be published in one
newspaper of general circulation in the Municipality for the following times:
      (1)    Notices for the advertisement for the acceptance of bids shall be
published not less than once a week for two consecutive weeks.
      (2)    All other matters shall be published once, except when otherwise
specifically required by law or by order of Council.
         (Ord. 2005-127. Passed 12-21-05.)

131.01 SECRETARY TO THE MAYOR.
   There is hereby created the position of Secretary to the Mayor. The
Secretary to the Mayor shall perform such duties as the Mayor assigns him or
her and shall receive such compensation as Council shall provide from time to
time. The Secretary to the Mayor shall not be required to give bond.
(Ord. 1987-22. Passed 3-18-87.)
131.02 HOUSING COMPLAINT REFERRAL OFFICER.
   (a)   Council authorizes the Mayor, on behalf of the Village, to serve as
the Housing Complaint Referral Officer of the Village or to designate such
other employee as the Mayor, in his discretion deems appropriate.
   (b)   The Housing Complaint Referral Officer shall receive and review all
complaints of housing discrimination, including complaints based upon race,
sex, handicapped or families with children alleged to occur in the Village.
   (c)   Each complaint should be referred to HUD for a complete investigation
of the charges in the complaint.
   (d)   The Housing Complaint Referral Officer should follow up every
complaint referral to HUD to monitor its progress and eventual outcome.
   (e)   The Housing Complaint Referral Officer shall refer all complaints to
such other agencies as are available in the community for handling
discrimination claims under the Act.
(Ord. 1989-30. Passed 4-19-89.)
131.03  MAYOR’S COURT CASH FUND.
   There is hereby appropriated, out of money in the General Fund not otherwise
appropriated, the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) which shall be known as
the Mayor’s Court Cash Revolving Fund. This fund shall be available for the
purposes of making change by the Clerk when fines are paid and shall be
replenished on a monthly basis in order to provide the sum of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) at all times for the fund.
(Ord. 1992-56. Passed 8-3-92.)
131.04 MAYOR’S COURT MAGISTRATE.
   (a)   There is hereby created the position of Mayor’s Court Magistrate to
perform the duties of Magistrate in a Mayor’s Court under the laws of the State
of Ohio. The Mayor’s Court Magistrate shall be appointed by the Mayor subject
to the confirmation of Council. The position of Mayor’s Court Magistrate shall
be a part-time position within the Village of Woodmere.
   (b)   The Mayor’s Court Magistrate shall receive such compensation as
Council shall from time to time establish and such compensation shall be paid
as payroll based upon hours submitted on a quarterly basis by the Mayor’s Court
Magistrate.
(Ord. 2001-145. Passed 11-19-01.)
131.05 MAYOR'S COURT IMPROVEMENT FUND.
   (a)   There is hereby created a fund to be known as the Mayor's Court
Improvement Fund. All applicable Mayor's Court costs received as "Mayor's Court
Improvement Fund" costs, shall be paid into such separate fund.
   (b)   Expenditures shall be made from the Mayor's Court Improvement Fund to
finance the computerization and/or the acquisition and/or maintenance of legal
research services for the Mayor's Court, including, but not limited to,
computer space; computer electrical; computer air-conditioning; computer
furniture; computer printer; computer software, subscription to computer
service(s); staff to operate the computer system, including fringes; supplies,
i.e. computer paper, etc.; training expenses; maintenance of equipment; and
computer needs studies.
(Ord. 1994-16. Passed 2-16-94.)
131.06  OFFICE MANAGER.
   There is hereby created the position of Office Manager. The Office Manager
shall perform job duties and tasks related to: Human Resources, including
payroll, workers’ compensation, and employee benefits; Building Department,
including permits, notices and reports; ambulance billing and monitoring; and
performing duties as back-up to the Assistant Treasurer, and all such similar
duties and tasks as may be prescribed by the Mayor or by the Treasurer, with
the approval of the Mayor. The Office Manager shall receive such compensation
as Council shall provide from time to time. The Office Manager shall be
directly supervised by the Treasurer and shall not be required to give bond.
(Ord. 2014-32. Passed 5-14-14.)
131.07 MAYOR’S COURT CLERK.
   The Mayor's Court Clerk shall be appointed by the Mayor and shall be
responsible to the Law Director with oversight by the Mayor of the general
function of the Mayor's Court as required by Chapter 1905 of the Ohio Revised
Code for the Woodmere Mayor's Court duties. The Mayor's Court Clerk shall be
governed by the general rules and regulations pertaining to employees of the
Village and shall perform the following duties:
   (a)   Duties as to the Woodmere Mayor's Court:
      (1)   Maintain all accounts involving moneys collected for fines,
waivers, bonds and miscellaneous reports;
      (2)   Responsible for making deposits and withdrawals from Mayor's Court,
Bail Bond, and State Fund as necessary;
      (3)   Type warrants and affidavits for Detective Bureaus and prepare
bench warrants for non-felony cases;
      (4)   Maintain a ledger of all court cases;
      (5)   Maintain ledger of all court cases in which a bond was given;
      (6)   Maintain a ledger listing all citations issued and amount of fine
taken;
      (7)   Receipt, post and close out all cases in which fines were taken by
Bedford Municipal Court;
      (8)   Prepare month end report in order to disburse funds to the State
and General Fund;
      (9)   Prepare license forfeitures for Ohio Bureau of Motor Vehicles (BMV)
and Compact State and Releases of Forfeitures;
      (10)   Prepare a monthly officers report for Chief of Police and Law
Director;
      (11)   Prepare dockets and cases for monthly court sessions;
      (12)   Prepare yearly court schedule for monthly court dates;
      (13)   Prepare purchase orders for Mayor's Court supplies and forms;
      (14)   Prepare delinquency notices for all court cases;
      (15)   Answer phones and assist callers with court inquiries and fine
schedules;
      (16)   Maintain court computer system, update software, and communicate
with support tech;
      (17)   Prepare driving privileges form issued by the court;
      (18)    Submit all assessed point violations to the Ohio Bureau of Motor
Vehicles (BMV) for processing on a monthly basis;
      (19)    Settle Mastercard/Visa and check card machine (if a transaction
has been conducted) at the end of the day;
      (20)   File all finished cases in numerical order;
      (21)   Maintain a copy of procedures for court activity;
      (22)   The Mayor's Court Clerk is the Violations Bureau Clerk for the
purpose of Traf. R. 13.
      (23)   Other duties as are assigned by the Law Director or Mayor.
   (b)   The part-time Mayor's Court Clerk shall be a part-time employee whose
hours shall not exceed twenty hours per week.
(Ord. 2019-60. Passed 11-13-19.)

133.01 PETTY CASH FUND.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
133.01  was repealed by Ordinance 2019-07, passed February 13, 2019.)
133.02 ASSISTANT TREASURER.
   (a)   There is hereby created the position of Assistant Treasurer. The job
skills required for this position shall include, although not be limited to, a
working knowledge of computers and office machines, business mathematics and
accounting, effective skills in oral and written business communications and
the ability to type. The Assistant Treasurer shall assist the Treasurer in the
performance of his duties as set forth in Section
133.05. The Assistant Treasurer shall receive such compensation as Council
shall provide from time to time, and shall be required to give bond.
   (b)   The Assistant Treasurer shall work in-person and within the
Treasurer’s office in Village Hall and perform the following duties:
      (1)   Assist with the daily operations of the Village.
         A.   Assist with in-coming calls as needed,
         B.   Process and respond to daily mail deliveries for Treasurer’s
office,
         C.   Greet and assist residents and visitor’s in a courteous and
professional manner at all times,
         D.   Project a professional image in all dealings with the public,
         E.   Prepare and type correspondence for Treasurer’s office,
         F.   Order all office supplies and postage,
         G.   Assist State auditors during regular and special audits,
         H.   Assist the Treasurer in training the accounting clerk.
         I.   Deposit computer back-up tapes in Village off site safe deposit
box.
      (2)   Prepare bi-weekly payroll for Village.
         A.   Maintain time clock and prepare time cards,
         B.   Audit time cards for accuracy and signatures of department
supervisors,
         C.   Input and update payroll data including deductions changes,
vacation and sick time, and holiday accumulations and personal data of
employees,
         D.   Prepare and distribute signed payroll checks,
         E.   Prepare payroll deduction checks and mail to proper agencies,
         F.   Prepare all pertinent payroll deposits for banking including
payroll tax deposits,
         G.   Update personnel records,
         H.   Serve as liaison with other agencies in personnel matters
concerning payroll information,
      (3)   Prepare accounts payable for processing.
         A.   Maintain purchase order system,
         B.   Sort vendor invoices and distribute to proper department for
verification and signature,
         C.   Input payable information onto computer system,
         D.   Process checks for authorized signature,
         E.   Mail checks to vendors,
         F.   Update accounts payable files,
         G.   Prepare monthly expenditure reports for distribution to Finance
committee.
      (4)   Serve as daily administrator for all incoming revenue.
         A.   Process all daily receipts from other departments,
         B.   Post receipts to proper accounts,
         C.   Deposit all receipts daily with designated depository,
         D.   Prepare bank reconciliation,
         E.   Prepare Treasurer’s Report and financial reports for distribution
to Mayor and Council,
         F.   Prepare accounts for month-end closing.
      (5)   Assist Treasurer with following reports for other agencies.
         A.   Public Employees Retirement System,
         B.   Police and Firemen’s Disability and Pension,
         C.   State of Ohio,
         D.   Regional Income Tax Agency,
         E.   Board of Building Standards,
         F.   Bureau of Workers Compensation,
         G.   Ohio Board of Building Standards,
         H.   Federal Tax Return Form 941,
         I.   Civil Rights Commission,
         J.   United States Census,
         K.   Federal Form W-2 for personnel,
         L.   Federal Form 1099 for vendor services,
      (6)   Provide assistance to, and perform other duties as assigned by, the
Treasurer, Mayor and Finance Committee as needed. 
         (Ord. 1996-78. Passed 10-16-96; Ord. 2025-05. Passed 2-12-25.)
133.03 ACCOUNTING TRANSACTIONS.
   The Manual for Recording and Processing Accounting Transactions shall be
reviewed and updated as determined by the Treasurer for all bookkeeping and
accounting records of the Village
(Ord. 1993-46. Passed 7-21-93.)
133.04 TRANSFER OF UNCLAIMED DEPOSITS TO GENERAL FUND.
   The Treasurer is hereby authorized and directed to transfer to the General
Fund any funds deposited pursuant to the ordinances, rules and regulations, or
requirements of the Village for excavation deposits, construction deposits,
house moving deposits, inspection deposits and any other unrefunded deposit
which has not been claimed by its lawful owner within five years from the date
of such deposit.
(Ord. 1993-46. Passed 7-21-93.)
133.05 APPOINTMENT AND DUTIES OF TREASURER.
   (a)    Appointment. Tbe Treasurer shall be appointed annually by Council and
may be removed by affirmative vote of five (5) members of Council at any time
during that period.
   (b)    Duties. In addition to the duties prescribed in the Charter for the
Treasurer, the Treasurer shall:
      (1)    Accounts of Receipts and Expenditures. Keep a full and accurate
account of all moneys received and disbursed by him/her on behalf of the
Municipality, specifying the time of receipt and disbursement, from whom
received and to whom disbursed, on what account received and disbursed, and how
paid;
      (2)    Audit Accounts. Examine and audit the accounts of all officers and
departments, subject to the approval of Council;
      (3)   Receive and Disburse Moneys. Receive and have custody of all moneys
paid to the Municipality, draw warrants upon the Municipal Treasury for the
amounts appropriated in the annual appropriation ordinance or amendments
thereto whenever claims are presented properly approved by the Mayor or by an
ordinance or resolution of Council to make the expenditures, and disburse money
upon a warrant issued therefor;
      (4)   Pay Municipal Employees. Pay Municipal employees upon presentation
of a properly certified payroll;
      (5)   Financial Statements. Transmit to Council at least monthly
statements of cash on hand and of classified unencumbered appropriation
balances for the Municipality as a whole, and such other financial statements
as Council may from time to time require, and keep all departments, boards and
commissions currently informed of their classified unencumbered appropriation
balances; and
      (6)   Custodian of Bonds, Contracts, etc. Be charged with the custody of
the official bonds of Municipal employees, except his/her own, which shall be
in the custody of the Mayor, and with the custody of all deeds, mortgages,
contracts, judgments, notes, debts, and choses in action. In addition, he/she
shall keep and administer all securities, bonds or other forms of negotiable
instruments owned by or belonging to the Municipality. (Ord. 2023-68. Passed
12-13-23.)
133.06 INVESTMENT OF SURPLUS MONEYS.
   Whenever there are moneys in the Municipal Treasury which will not be
required to be used for a period of six months or more, such moneys may, in
lieu of being deposited in a bank or banks, be invested in accordance with the
provisions of Ohio R.C. 731.56 et seq. Investments so purchased shall be sold
in accordance with Ohio R.C. 731.57.
(Ord. 1993-46. Passed 7-21-93.)
133.07 STATE TREASURY ASSET RESERVE PROGRAM.
   (a)   The Municipality, by and through its Treasurer, is hereby authorized
to participate in the State Treasury Asset Reserve of Ohio Program (Star Ohio)
and is further authorized to establish such accounts as Council may require for
accounting convenience and to satisfy requirements regarding the commingling of
funds.
   (b)   The Treasurer is hereby authorized to make application for the
establishment of accounts referred to in subsection (a) hereof and to take such
further action as is necessary to provide for the effective investment of funds
of the Municipality.
(Ord. 1993-46. Passed 7-21-93.)
133.08 CLERK OF COUNCIL DUTIES.
   (a)   The Clerk shall attend all Council meetings and keep all records of
their proceedings, rules, by-laws, resolutions and ordinances, passed or
adopted. These shall be subject to inspection by any interested party.
 
   (b)   The Clerk shall place legal advertisements in publications when
required and prepare the agenda for regular or special Council meetings.
 
   (c)   The Clerk will sign documents requiring the Clerk's signature for
other governmental agencies.
(Ord. 1993-46. Passed 7-21-93.)
133.09 MINUTES AND RECORDS.
   (a)   The Clerk of Council shall, in addition to all other duties prescribed
by the Charter or ordinance, have the care, custody and control of all minutes
and records of Council and of the boards and commissions of which he/she is
Secretary.
(Ord. 1993-46. Passed 7-21-93.)
   (b)   The original minutes and records under the care, custody and control
of the Clerk of Council shall be safely kept at such place or places within the
Village owned property as the Clerk of Council may deem proper for their
preservation and protection.
   (c)   No person shall remove or take any original minutes, records or
legislation under the care, custody and control of the Clerk of Council from
Village owned property except as may be required to comply with a summons or
subpoena of a court or agency of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 2019-35. Passed
8-7-19.)
 
   (d)   The original of minutes or records under the care, custody and control
of the Clerk of Council shall be made readily available for inspection by any
person interested in the same at reasonable hours during the work day.
 
   (e)   A copy of all minutes, records and legislation shall be prepared and
supplied to the Mayor and Council without charge.
   (f)   Copies of minutes, records and legislation, other than those referred
to in subsection (e) hereof, shall be reproduced and given to any person
requesting the same, provided however, that the Clerk of Council may require
the payment of a reasonable fee to cover the expense of reproduction.
(Ord. 1993-46. Passed 7-21-93.)
133.10 COPYING AND CERTIFYING DOCUMENTS.
   The Clerk of Council is hereby authorized and directed to charge the
following fees for copying and certifying documents:
 
(a) For Copying Documents.
    (1) One page or less                                           $.05
    (2) Each additional page                                       .05
(b) For Certifying Documents.
    (1) Per certification                                          1.00
(c) For complete copies of the Planning and and Zoning Code of the 25.00
    Codified Ordinances
    (Ord. 2000-08. Passed 2-16-00.)
133.11 CHECK SIGNATURES.
   (a)   All checks and warrants issued by the Village of Woodmere shall be
signed by the Treasurer as an authorized signatory on any check or warrant. In
the event the Treasurer is unavailable for any extended period of time, in the
event of any emergency situation or in the event of a pre-approved situation,
the Mayor or the Council President are designated as alternate signatory for
any checks or warrants of the Municipality which have been properly authorized
by Council and for which the funds have been appropriated.
   (b)   The Mayor shall make necessary arrangements with the financial
institution for the Village to execute any and all necessary signature cards
under the authority of this section.
(Ord. 2001-146. Passed 11-19-01.)
133.12 ACCOUNTING CLERK.
   The Accounting Clerk shall assist the Treasurer on a daily basis. The
Accounting Clerk position shall be a part-time position to be filled as needed
to and no more than thirty hours per week. (Ord. 2025-06. Passed 2-12-25.)
133.13 PURCHASE OF FOOD AND BEVERAGES FOR MEETINGS, PROGRAMS, AND STAFF EVENTS.
   Council hereby authorizes the Mayor, Council President, and Treasurer to
purchase food and beverages for meetings, programs and other staff events
regarding Village business, including employee holiday gatherings in an annual
amount not to exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000).
(Ord. 2019-12. Passed 3-13-19.)
133.14 MOBILE PHONE.
   The Treasurer shall be provided with a mobile phone which shall be used for
all Village business with the expenses of the mobile phone being paid by the
Village.
(Ord. 2025-16. Passed 5-14-25.)
CHAPTER 135
Law Director
135.01     Duties.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Appointment, removal, duties - see CHTR. Art. V
Sec. 4
Conflict of interest - see Ohio R.C. 120.39
 
135.01 DUTIES.
   (a)    The position of Law Director is created.
   (b)    The Law Director shall prosecute or defend any and all suits or
actions at law or equity to which the Village may be a party, or in which it
may be interested, or which may be brought against, or by, any official of the
Village on behalf of the Village, or in the capacity of such person as an
official of the Village.
   (c)    The Law Director shall see to the full enforcement of all judgments
or decrees rendered or entered in favor of the Village and of all similar
interlocutory orders.
   (d)    The Law Director shall be the legal advisor of the Village and shall
render advice on all legal questions affecting the Village, whenever requested
to do so by any Village official. Upon request by the Mayor or by Council, the
Law Director shall reduce any such opinion to writing.
   (e)    The Law Director shall see to the completion of all special
assessment proceedings and condemnation proceedings.
   (f)    The Law Director shall draft or supervise the phraseology of any
contract, lease, or other documents or instruments, to which the Village may be
a party; and upon request of Council, shall draft ordinances covering any
subjects within the power of the Village.
   (g)    (1)    The Law Director shall serve as legal advisor to Council, and
to Village officials and employees on matters pertaining to their duties, shall
represent the Village in litigation except where Council directs otherwise,
shall draft all contracts, ordinances, or other documents needed by the
Village, shall attend Council meetings, Planning and Zoning meetings, and shall
render such other legal service as may be required by Council.
      (2)    The Law Director shall receive for services a retainer in a sum as
set by Council which shall be full compensation for all advisory services,
attendance at Council and Planning and Zoning meetings, and the drafting of
ordinances, contracts, and other documents.
   (h)    The monthly retainer fee shall not include those services rendered in
connection with bond issues, or with research, preparation, and attendance in
any court, or with research, preparation, and attendance in all matters and
hearings to which the Village or its officials or employees in their official
capacity may be parties. For any services not covered by the retainer, legal
counsel shall receive an hourly rate as set by Council.
(1973 Code Sec. 30.02.)
CHAPTER 136
Department of Public Safety
136.01   Establishment; appointment; duties.
136.02    Salary benefits.
136.01 ESTABLISHMENT; APPOINTMENT; DUTIES.
   (a)    A Department of Public Safety is hereby established under the
authority of
Article V, Section 1 , of the Charter of the Village of Woodmere, with the
Departments of Police, Fire and Building being divisions within the Department
of Public Safety. The Director of Public Safety shall be the head of the
Department of Public Safety.
   (b)    The Mayor, in addition to his or her other duties, shall be, and
shall perform the duties of, the Director of Public Safety. However, the Mayor
may decline the position of Director Of Public Safety. In that case, the
Director of Public Safety shall then be appointed by the Mayor, within 90 days
of the Mayor declining the position. The Mayor’s appointment of the Director of
Public Safety shall be subject to confirmation by a vote of four (4) members of
Council.
   (c)    The Director of Public Safety shall supervise the Police Chief, Fire
Chief and Building Inspector and shall be ultimately responsible for the
enforcement of all police, fire, health, safety and sanitary regulations, and
all of the provisions of the building and zoning codes, and all such similar
regulations, codes, laws and ordinances, that may be prescribed by resolutions
and ordinances of the Village or laws of Ohio.
(Ord. 2014-03. Passed 3-19-14.)
136.02 SALARY; BENEFITS.
   (a)   Salary. The annual salary of the Director of Public Safety shall be
fixed by the Council.
   (b)   Vehicle Allowance. The Director of Public Safety shall receive an
annual vehicle allowance in an amount set by Council, by motion, after
consultation with the Treasurer. The vehicle allowance shall be used to
purchase, lease or own, operate and maintain a personal vehicle. The vehicle
allowance shall be paid in equal payments on a monthly basis or another
schedule as recommended by the Treasurer. The Director of Public Safety shall
be responsible for paying for liability, property damage and comprehensive
insurance coverage upon such vehicle and shall further be responsible for
gasoline, oil and all expenses attendant to the operation, maintenance, repair
and regular replacement of the vehicle.
   (c)   Mileage Reimbursement. The Director of Public Safety shall be
reimbursed at the mileage rate and in accordance with the guidelines,
established by the Internal Revenue Service for all business use of the
vehicle. The Director of Public Safety shall maintain a mileage log and submit
it monthly to the Treasurer.
   (d)   Mobile Phone. The Director of Public Safety shall be provided with a
mobile phone to be used for Village business with the expenses of the mobile
phone being paid by the Village. (Ord. 2018-05. Passed 2-14-18.)
CHAPTER 137
Department of Public Service
137.01   Establishment; appointment; duties.

137.01 ESTABLISHMENT; APPOINTMENT; DUTIES.
   (a)   A Department of Public Service is hereby established under the
authority of Article V,
 Section 1 , of the Charter of the Village of Woodmere. All services previously
performed under the duties of Street Commissioner are hereby assigned to the
Director of Public Service.
   (b)   The duties of the Director of Public Service shall be as prescribed by
the Ohio Revised Code, and in addition, the Director of Public Service shall be
responsible for keeping the roads and the streets of the Village free from
snow, and shall perform such other duties as Council from time to time may
request.
   (c)   The Service Director shall be charged with the duty of the enforcement
of any housing maintenance code, zoning code and general offenses dealing with
building, housing and other nuisance legislation adopted by the Village and
shall be responsible for keeping accurate and complete records of activities in
connection with the enforcement of any housing maintenance code provisions of
the Codified Ordinances. He shall perform such other duties as directed by the
Mayor or Building Inspector.
(Ord. 1994-89. Passed 11-16-94.)
137.02 CHIEF VILLAGE IMPROVEMENT INSPECTOR.
   (a)   The Director of Public Service shall perform the duties of Chief
Village Improvement Inspector on all pending and future improvements within the
Village. The Chief Village Improvement Inspector may from time to time, at his
discretion, designate other individuals to function in his stead.
   (b)   The Municipality shall receive as compensation for the services of the
Inspector the sum of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per hour. The person or entity
obtaining a building permit shall be financially responsible for remitting this
compensation to the Municipality. At the time of the issuance of the building
permit, the person or entity shall file a bond or cash with the Village in
sufficient amount to cover such payment. The person or entity who obtained the
building permit shall be responsible for notifying the Chief Village
Improvement Inspector of necessary inspection work at least twenty-four hours
prior to the time when the inspection is to be made.
(Ord. 1994-89. Passed 11-16-94.)
137.03 DEPUTY VILLAGE IMPROVEMENT INSPECTORS. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
137.03  was repealed by Ordinance 2006-55, passed July 19, 2006.)
137.04 ASSISTANT SERVICE DIRECTOR.
   There is hereby created the position of Assistant Service Director. The
Assistant Service Director shall receive such compensation as is provided by
Council from time to time, and shall not be required to give bond. Whenever
reference is made in the Codified Ordinances of the Village to Street
Commissioner, it shall mean Service Director.
(Ord. 1994-89. Passed 11-16-94.)
CHAPTER 139
Planning and Zoning Commission
139.01   Planning Commission.
139.02   Variances; rules and regulations.
139.03   Appeal procedure.
139.04   Compensation. (Repealed)
 
CROSS REFERENCES

Sec. 8(A)

Sec. 8(B)

139.01 PLANNING COMMlSSlON.
   (a)   A Planning Commission for the Village is hereby established and
created.
   (b)   The Commission shall administer the planning and zoning code and
building regulations.
   (c)   The Planning Commission shall employ the services of the Regional
Planning Commission of Cuyahoga County as an advisory board on planning, zoning
and applications for building permits submitted to the Village, except on
building applications of less than two thousand dollars ($2,000) which shall be
approved by the building inspector, unless the building inspector requests a
Planning Commission review of the application. The Planning Commission shall
request an advisory opinion from the Regional Planning Commission when approved
by a vote of the Commission. The report and recommendation of the Regional
Planning Commission shall be made a part of the Planning Commission record,
however, the same shall be advisory and non-binding.
(Ord. 1981- 38. Passed 9-16-81.)
139.02 VARIANCES; RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall determine all matters properly
presented to it and where practical difficulties and unnecessary hardships
shall result from the strict compliance with or the enforcement of the
provisions of Chapter
1317  and/or Chapter
1321 , such Commission shall have the power to grant variances in harmony with
the general intent of such ordinances and to secure the general welfare and
substantial justice in the promotion of the public health, comfort,
convenience, morals, safety and general welfare of the City. The Commission
shall also have the power to adopt from time to time such rules and regulations
as it may deem necessary to carry into effect the provisions of any ordinance
for which it is designated as the Board of Appeals or Board of Review.
(Ord. 1989-29. Passed 4-19-89.)
139.03 APPEAL PROCEDURE.
   (a)   Any person adversely affected by a decision of any City official made
in the enforcement of any ordinance for which the Planning and Zoning
Commission is designated for appeals shall have the right to appeal to the
Planning and Zoning Commission from such decision within thirty days from the
date notice of such decision was given or mailed to him unless a shorter time
is provided for in a specific ordinance, and to appear before the Commission at
a time and place fixed by the Commission. Such appeal must be in writing.
Failure to file a written appeal with the Commission within the time prescribed
shall constitute a waiver of the right of appeal. The Commission shall have the
power to approve, amend, modify or reverse any decision of such City official.
   (b)   Any person adversely affected by a decision of the Planning and Zoning
Commission shall also have the right to appeal to Council from such decision
within ten days from the date notice of such decision was given or mailed to
the appellant, and to appear before Council at a time and place fixed by
Council. Such appeal must be in writing. Failure to file a written appeal with
Council within the time prescribed shall constitute a waiver of the right of
appeal. Council shall have the power to approve, amend, modify or reverse any
decision of the Planning and Zoning Commission.
(Ord. 1989-29. Passed 4-19-89.)
139.04 COMPENSATION. (REPEALED)
   EDITOR'S NOTE: former Section
139.04 was repealed by Ordinance 1995-27, passed March 15, 1995.

CHAPTER 143
Village Architect
143.01   Established.
143.02   Appointment; compensation.
143.03   Duties.
143.04   Conflict of interest; unavailability.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Architectural Review Board - see CHTR. Art. V,
Sec. 2
 
143.01  ESTABLISHED.
   The positions of Village Architect and Alternate Village Architect are
established within the municipality. The Village Architect and Alternate
Village Architect shall be registered in the State of Ohio with at least five
years of professional experience and meet the requirements of a Plans Examiner
as defined by the Ohio Basic Building Code. The duties of both the Village
Architect and Alternate Village Architect shall be as set out for the Village
Architect in the following sections of this Chapter. The Mayor shall determine
the assignment of duties between the Village Architect and the Alternate
Village Architect.
(Ord. 1997-76. Passed 2-18-98.)
143.02 APPOINTMENT; COMPENSATION.
   (a)   The Mayor, subject to the confirmation of Council, shall appoint a
Village Architect and Alternate Village Architect for terms of one year. Should
no action be taken at the expiration of their terms, the Village Architect and
Alternate Village Architect shall continue to serve until qualified successors
are appointed and confirmed.
   (b)   The rate at which the Village Architect and Alternate Village
Architect are to be compensated shall be established by Council.
(Ord. 1997-76. Passed 2-18-98.)
143.03  DUTIES.
   (a)   The Village Architect shall review all building permit applications,
together with accompanying plans, drawings and specifications, for any building
or any other structure to be built in the Village, and which are subject to the
Ohio Basic Building Code. The Village Architect shall review plans to determine
conformance with the minimum requirements of the Ohio Basic Building Code and
the amendments, if any, adopted by the Village thereto, governing the erection,
construction, repair, alteration and maintenance of buildings and structures.
The Village Architect shall approve or disapprove all applications in writing;
no permit shall be issued without such written approval.
   (b)   The Village Architect shall consult with the Mayor and other
department heads, and assist the Council on legislative matters relating to
building code compliance or construction practices or standards. The Village
Architect shall further perform such other duties as may be assigned by the
Mayor.
(Ord. 1986-96. Passed 12-29-86.)
143.04 CONFLICT OF INTEREST; UNAVAILABILITY.
   The Village Architect shall not participate in any review of any work
wherein he or any of his partners or professional associates is the author or
in which he or they have any direct or indirect financial interests. In such
event, or in the event of the unavailability of the Village Architect, the
Mayor shall direct another architect having the qualifications required by this
chapter to serve as the "acting Village Architect" at the same compensation
rate as the Village Architect.
(Ord. 1986-96. Passed 12-29-86.)

Police Department
