145.01 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The official rules and regulations for the Police Department are on file and
available upon request in the Treasurer’s office.
145.02 COMPOSITION; RANK.
   (a)   The Police Department shall be composed of such officers of such rank
as shall from time to time be established by Council.
   (b)   All officers whose rank has been removed from the chain of command
shall revert to the position of patrolman.
145.03 UNIFORMS.
   All police officers shall wear the complete uniform of their office at all
times while on duty, and shall maintain a neat and clean appearance at all
times.
(1973 Code Sec. 32.03)
145.04 PSYCHOLOGICAL EXAMINATIONS.
   (a)   Each and every applicant for a full-time or part-time position within
the Police Department, including the Chief of Police, pursuant to Ohio R.C.
737.15, 737.16 or 737.161, shall present to the Mayor, via the Chief of Police,
evidence of successful completion of a psychological examination.
      (1)   This psychological examination shall be of a type administered by
an organization or individual approved by the Mayor.
      (2)   Each applicant shall fulfill the requirements of subsection (a)
hereof, prior to commencing his or her probationary period, pursuant to Ohio
R.C. 737.17, or prior to appointment under Ohio R.C. 737.161.
      (3)   In order to have validity for purposes of this section, the
psychological examination shall have been administered no later than six months
prior to the beginning of the applicant’s probationary period, pursuant to Ohio
R.C. 737.17, or prior to the applicant’s appointment pursuant to Ohio R.C.
737.161.
(Ord. 2001-148. Passed 11-19-01.)
   (b)   Upon the recommendation of the Police Chief for good cause shown and
approval of the Mayor, a full-time or part-time police officer shall undergo,
at the Village’s cost a complete psychological reexamination.
      (1)   This psychological reexamination shall be of a type administered by
an organization or individual approved by the Mayor.
      (2)   Failure to pass any reexamination shall constitute grounds for
termination from employment with the Village.
   (c)   Upon recommendation of the Mayor for good cause shown, the Police
Chief shall undergo, at the Village’s cost a complete psychological
reexamination.
      (1)   This psychological reexamination shall be of a type administered by
an organization or individual approved by the Mayor.
      (2)   Failure to pass any reexamination shall constitute grounds for
termination from employment with the Village.
         (Ord. 1994-66. Passed 8-3-94.)
145.05 PHYSICAL EXAMINATIONS.
   Every full-time police officer of the Village, including the Chief of
Police, shall after confirmation as a regular police officer be examined once
every two years by competent doctors, including eye examination, to confirm
that each police officer is in good health and able to carry out his or her
duties.
(Ord. 1994-66. Passed 8-3-94.)
145.06 OUTSIDE EMPLOYMENT LIMITED.
   (a)   All full-time police officers shall be required to limit their outside
employment in the following manner:
      (1)   No full-time police officer of the Village shall be employed in any
outside employment for more than twenty hours in any work week.
      (2)   No full-time police officer of the Village shall be employed in any
outside employment for four hours or more within the eight hours immediately
proceeding the beginning of such police officer’s regularly scheduled shift of
duty.
   (b)   Any police officer requesting a temporary waiver of this section shall
make an application in writing to the Chief of Police, who may, for unusual
circumstances or hardships, grant temporary waivers of this section upon the
assurance that the intent of this section will be met. The Chief shall report
the waiver to Council, in writing, at its next meeting.
   (c)   Any violation of this chapter shall be grounds for suspension or
dismissal.
(Ord. 1980-54. Passed 2-18-81.)
 
145.07 PART-TIME; PROBATIONARY OFFICERS.
   (a)   No part-time police officers of the Village shall be employed for more
than thirty-two hours in any calendar week.
   (b)    Any full-time probationary employee of the Village who requires
confirmation of Council and who is not confirmed shall not again be employed by
the Village in a similar position for a period of two years.
(Ord. 1991-41. Passed 7-17-91.)
   (c)   Part time personnel hired by the Police Department must work a minimum
of four eight hour shifts per month to maintain employment status. The Chief of
Police is hereby authorized to suspend and/or terminate employment for non-
compliance.
(Ord. 1999-40. Passed 6-16-99.)
145.08 NON-UNIFORM PERSONNEL.
   There are hereby established in the Police Department the following
positions to be appointed by the Mayor, to receive such compensation as Council
may from time to time provide:
   (a)   Clerk of the Police Department, full-time.
   (b)   Part-time Police Clerk.
(Ord. 1993-49. Passed 7-21 -93.)
145.09 TRAFFIC VIOLATIONS BUREAU.
   (a)   Establishment and Operation of Traffic Violations Bureau. Each court,
other than the juvenile division of the court of common pleas, shall establish
a Traffic Violations Bureau. The court shall appoint its clerk as violations
clerk. If there is no clerk, the court shall appoint any appropriate person of
the municipality or county in which the court sits. The violations bureau and
violations clerk shall be under the direction and control of the court. Fines
and costs shall be paid to, receipted by and accounted for by the violations
clerk.
   The violations bureau shall accept appearance, waiver of trial, plea of
guilty, and payment of fine and costs for offenses within its authority.
   (b)   Authority of Violations Bureau. All traffic offenses except those
listed in subsection (b)(1) to (9) may be disposed of by a Traffic Violations
Bureau. The following traffic offenses shall not be processed by a Traffic
Violations Bureau:
      (1)   Indictable offenses;
      (2)   Operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or
any drug of abuse;
      (3)   Leaving the scene of an accident;
      (4)   Driving while under suspension or revocation of a driver’s license;
      (5)   Driving without being licensed to drive, except where the driver’s
or commercial driver’s license had been expired for six months or less;
      (6)   A third moving traffic offense within a twelve-month period;
      (7)   Failure to stop and remain standing upon meeting or overtaking a
school bus stopped on the highway for the purpose of receiving or discharging a
school child;
      (8)   Willfully eluding or fleeing a police officer;
      (9)   Drag racing.
   (c)   Schedule of Fines. The court shall establish and publish a schedule of
fines and costs for all offenses. The schedule shall be distributed to all law
enforcement agencies operating within the jurisdiction of the court and shall
be prominently displayed at the place in the violations bureau where fines are
paid.
   (d)   Defendant’s Appearance, Plea and Waiver of Trial.  
      (1)   Within seven days after the date of issuance of the ticket, a
defendant charged with an offense that can be processed by a traffic violations
bureau may do either of the following:
         A.   Appear in person at the Traffic Violations Bureau, sign a plea of
guilty and waiver of trial provision of the ticket, and pay the total amount of
the fine and costs;
         B.   Sign the guilty plea and waiver of trial provision of the ticket
and mail the ticket and a check, money order, or other approved form of payment
for the total amount of the fine and costs to the Traffic Violations Bureau;
      (2)   A court may establish a procedure for accepting, through its
traffic violations bureau, guilty pleas, waivers of trial, and payments of
fines and costs by telephone or other electronic means. The form of payment
accepted by telephone or other electronic means shall be approved by the
bureau.
      (3)   Remittance of the fine and costs to the Traffic Violations Bureau
by an means other than personal appearance by the defendant at the bureau
constitutes a guilty plea and waiver of trial whether or not the guilty plea
and waiver of trial provision of the ticket are signed by the defendant.
   (e)   Records. All cases processed in the Violations Bureau shall be
numbered and recorded for identification and statistical purposes. In any
statistical reports required by law, the number of cases disposed of by the
Violations Bureau shall be listed separately from those disposed of in open
court.
   (f)   Hours of Operation; Personnel. The court shall appoint a law
enforcement officer as a Deputy Violations Bureau Clerk to act as Violations
Clerk when the Violations Clerk is not on duty.
(Ord. 2000-26. Passed 4-19-00.)
145.10  DUTIES OF MAYOR’S COURT CLERK. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
145.10  was repealed by Ordinance 2019-08, passed January 9, 2019. See Section
131.07 for relevant provisions.)
145.11 DUTIES OF FULL-TIME POLICE CLERK.
   There is hereby established within the Division of Police the position of
full-time Police Clerk who shall be appointed by the Mayor and who shall be
under the control and supervision of the Police Chief.
   (a)   Duties as to the full-time Police Clerk:
      (1)   Record all dispositions from traffic and criminal courts; prepare
traffic criminal cases for transfer to Bedford Municipal Court;
      (2)   Verify active warrants for monthly validations required by LEADS;
      (3)   Order police department office supplies;
      (4)   Sort mail;
      (5)   Check files each month to insure that all reports are filed in
numerical order and accounted for;
      (6)   Answer phones and direct calls to appropriate personnel;
      (7)   Assist with walk-in inquiries;
      (8)   Assist Mayor’s Court Clerk in collecting fines and waiver;
      (9)   Assist Mayor’s Court Clerk as authorized by the Safety Director,
Police Chief and/or Law Director;
      (10)   Prepare warrants and affidavits for the Detective Bureau and
Patrolman for apprehension of wanted parties;
      (11)   Assist in typing and filing jackets for traffic citations;
      (12)   Process requests for police reports and receipt monies and turn in
to the Treasurer’s Office;
      (13)   Maintain parking violations (file in numerical order and send
notices as needed);
      (14)   Retrieve and copy all accident reports made by request from
insurance companies and attorneys;
      (15)   Update all Bedford Municipal Court cases in computer/file box as
they are disposed of by the Ohio Bureau of Motor Vehicle (BMV);
      (16)   Other duties as are assigned by the Police Chief.
   (b)   The Police Clerk shall be designated as full-time or part-time as
necessary by the Mayor and Police Chief and shall receive such compensation as
Council shall from time to time provide. (Ord. 2019-61. Passed 11-13-19.)
   
145.12  DUTIES OF PART-TIME POLICE CLERK. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
145.12  was repealed by Ordinance 2019-61, passed November 13, 2019.)
145.13 MINIMUM PAY FOR OFF-DUTY COURT APPEARANCES.
   Off-duty Village Police Officers shall receive a minimum of two hours
regular pay for court appearances effective June 23, 1999.
(Ord. 1999-41. Passed 6-16-99.)
145.14 PART-TIME DEPUTY CHIEF.
   Effective February 14, 2024, the position of part-time Deputy Chief is
established within the Police Department, to assist in the overall management
of the Police Department and perform such duties as required by the Police
Chief and Safety Director.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 2-14-24.)

147.01 ASSISTANT FIRE CHIEF.
   The position of assistant fire chief is established within the Municipality.
(1973 Code Sec. 32.05. )
147.02 FIRE DEPARTMENT LIEUTENANTS.
   (a)   Pursuant to statutory authority there is created the office of Fire
Lieutenant under the direction of the Fire Chief who shall have the power and
duty to be present at all fires, run the day to day operations of the Fire
Department, coordinate and control the flow of fire calls, be in charge of
specific categories regarding the Fire Department, delegate tasks to specific
people, and to do and perform all other acts necessary to effect the discharge
of these duties.
   (b)   The Fire Lieutenant shall be appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by
Council and shall serve until removed by office by the Mayor or the office is
otherwise vacated.
(Ord. 2000-12. Passed 12-16-00.)
147.03 FIRE INSPECTOR AND THE INVESTIGATION OF FIRES.
   (a)   Pursuant to statutory authority there is created the office of Fire
Inspector who shall have the power and duty to be present at all fires,
investigate the cause thereof, examine witnesses, compel the attendance of
witnesses and the production of books and papers, and to do and perform all
other acts necessary to effect the discharge of these duties.
   (b)   The Fire Inspector may administer oaths, make arrests, and enter, for
the purpose of examination, any building which, in his opinion, is in danger
from fire. He shall report his proceedings to Council at such times as they
require.
   (c)   The Fire Inspector shall be appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by
Council and shall serve until removed from office by the Mayor or the office is
otherwise vacated. The Fire Inspector shall serve without compensation.
(1973 Code Sec. 32.07. )
147.04 VOLUNTEER FIREMEN'S DEPENDENTS FUND BOARD.
   (a)   A volunteer Firemen's Dependents Fund Board is established pursuant to
Ohio R.C. 146.02, and shall consist of five members elected and organized in
accordance with Ohio R.C. 146.03 through 146.06.
   (b)    All volunteer firemen of the Village are beneficiaries of these funds
and shall receive the benefits specified in Ohio R.C. 146.12 in accordance with
the procedure designated in Ohio R.C. Chapter 146.
(Ord. 1976-41. Passed 9-15-76.)
147.05 EMERGENCY MEDICAL TECHNICIAN.
   (a)   There is hereby established an Emergency Medical Technician Unit
within the Fire Department of the Village of Woodmere. The Emergency Medical
Technician Unit shall be composed of up to a maximum of thirty-five members.
   (b)   The members of the Emergency Medical Technician Unit shall be
appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the Mayor. The Fire Chief shall be
responsible for the overall supervision of the Emergency Medical Technician
Unit and shall have control of the assignment, training, stationing and
direction of work for the members of the unit.
   (c)   All services performed by the Emergency Medical Technician Unit
members shall be on a voluntary basis and no member shall be entitled to any
benefits or relief or pension funds of the Village with the State of Ohio or
any other similar benefit.
   (d)   The members of the Emergency Medical Technician Unit shall receive
such compensation as Council shall designate in its wage ordinances including
the following:
      (1)   Each member shall be paid the fixed sum when responding and
transporting for each ambulance run when not connected with a fire call.
      (2)   Each member shall receive compensation at a fixed rate per hour for
service on ambulance runs in connection with fire calls. Each member shall be
paid a minimum of one hour at the fixed hourly rate for the first hour or any
portion thereof and shall be paid for all time for service after the first hour
at the fixed hourly rate.
      (3)   Each member shall receive compensation at a fixed rate per hour for
time expended in training at Village Hall to maintain certification as an
emergency medical technician.
      (4)   Each member shall receive compensation at a fixed rate required to
remain at the fire station on standby for emergency medical services.
   (e)   Applicants for Emergency Medical Technician must have and maintain a
current Ohio EMT, National Registry and CPR Certificate.
   (f)   To maintain active EMS status, members of the Emergency Medical
Technician Unit must:
      (1)   Work a minimum of forty hours station time per month unless an
exception is granted by the Fire Chief; and
      (2)   Attend at least fifty percent (50%) of the monthly EMS In Service
Training Sessions.
(Ord. 2001-151. Passed 11-19-01.)
147.06 EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICE UNIT COORDINATOR.
   (a)   There is hereby established the position of Emergency Medical Service
Unit Coordinator within the Fire Department of the Village of Woodmere.
   (b)   It shall be the duty and responsibility of the Emergency Medical
Service Unit Coordinator to perform the following duties and responsibilities:
      (1)   Be responsible for and oversee the Emergency Medical Service Unit
and report directly to the Chief of the Fire Department of the Village.
      (2)   Maintain all records related to the Emergency Medical Service Unit.
      (3)   Be responsible for the supervision of Emergency Medical Technicians
and ascertaining that all certificates required are continued in good standing.
      (4)   Determine the necessary continuing educational obligations for
Emergency Medical Technicians and make provisions for completion of any
continuing education requirements.
      (5)   Be in charge of the assignment, stationing and scheduling of
personnel.
      (6)   Be responsible for ordering supplies and maintaining necessary
supplies for the operation of the Emergency Medical Service Unit.
      (7)   Be responsible for following up of any required in-service training
of Emergency Medical Technicians.
      (8)   Review and maintain Emergency Medical Technician personnel records.
      (9)   Perform all other duties and functions as delegated by the Chief of
the Fire Department or the Council of the Village.
         (Ord. 1992-74. Passed 11-18-92.)
   (c)    The Emergency Medical Service Unit Coordinator shall be appointed by
the Mayor, serve at the pleasure of the Mayor and shall receive no compensation
for such service.
(Ord. 1993-78. Passed 11-17-93.)
CHAPTER 149
Department of Building
149.01   Establishment; direction and control.

149.01 ESTABLISHMENT; DIRECTION AND CONTROL.
   There is hereby established a Department of Building which shall be directed
and controlled by a Building Inspector who shall perform the duties set forth
in this chapter.
(Ord. 1994-37. Passed 4-20-94.)
149.02 PERSONNEL.
   The Department of Building shall be composed of the following personnel who
shall be appointed by the Mayor and shall receive compensation as Council shall
designate from time to time:
   (a)   Building Inspector. The Building Inspector shall be appointed by the
Mayor, subject to the confirmation of Council, to serve at the pleasure of the
Mayor.
      (Ord. 1994-92. Passed 11-16-94.)
   (b)   Assistant Building Inspector. The Assistant Building Inspector shall
be appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by Council, to serve at the
pleasure of the Mayor, and shall assist the Building Inspector in fulfilling
the duties and responsibilities of the position of Building Inspector.
      (Ord. 2014-36. Passed 4-9-14.)
149.03 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF BUILDING INSPECTOR.
   The Building Inspector shall be charged with the following duties and
responsibilities.
   (a)   The Building Inspector shall be in charge of the Building Department
and shall be responsible for the receiving, handling and disposition of all
applications for permits and for the issuance of all types of permits required
by these Codified Ordinances, subject, however, to the approval of such
committee, commission or board as may be required in these Codified Ordinances.
   (b)   He shall be responsible for the enforcement of the Planning and Zoning
Code and the Building Code and all other ordinances, resolutions and procedures
of the Village affecting construction, repairing, remodeling, removal or razing
any structure as well as the use of any structure or land within the City.
   (c)   He shall be responsible for making all inspections required and
keeping a record thereof.
   (d)   He shall advise and assist the Mayor, the Planning and Zoning
Commission and other City officials with reference to their departments.
   (e)   He shall be responsible for the keeping of accurate and complete
records of all Building Department activities and the charging and collection
of all fees in connection with permits. Immediately upon receipt thereof, he
shall forward the same to the Treasurer and receive a receipt therefor.
   (f)   He shall assist the County health authorities in such matters as may
be required involving the health matters affecting the Village.
   (g)   He shall have the power and duty to halt any construction, repairing,
remodeling, removal and razing of any structure or lands not being used in
accordance with these Codified Ordinances or any other Village ordinance,
resolution or regulation relevant thereto.
      (Ord. 1994-37. Passed 4-20-94.)
   (h)   The Building Inspector shall hold a Class 3 certification as Building
Inspector as well as a Class 1 certification as Building Official for purposes
of the Ohio Basic Building Code (OBBC) and shall be considered the Village’s
Building Official thereunder.
(Ord. 1996-14. Passed 2-21-96.)

CHAPTER 153
Affirmative Action Procedure
153.01    Definitions.
153.02    Contract compliance.
153.03    Equal employment opportunity clause.
153.04    Contract compliance requirements.
153.05    Intergovernmental cooperation.
153.06    Severability.
153.07    Civil Rights Compliance.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Unlawful discriminatory practices - see Ohio R.C. 4112.02
 
153.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)    "Discriminate," "discriminates," and "discrimination" mean
distinguish, differentiate, separate or segregate solely on the basis of race,
religion, color, sex or national origin.
   (b)    "Contractor" means any person, partnership, corporation, association
or joint venture which has been awarded a publically bid construction contract
and includes every subcontractor on such a contract.
    (c)    "Subcontractor" means any person, partnership, corporation,
association or joint venture which supplies any of the work, labor, services,
supplies, equipment, materials or any combination of the foregoing under a
contract with the contractor on a publically bid construction contract.
   (d)    "Public contract" means any contract awarded by the Village whereby
the Village is committed to expend or does expend its funds in return for work,
labor, services, supplies, equipment, materials, or any combination of the
foregoing, or any lease, lease by way of concession, concession agreement
permit or permit agreement whereby the Village leases, grants, or demises
property of the Village or otherwise grants a right or privilege to occupy or
use property of the Village.
   (e)    "Bidder" means any person, partnership, corporation, association or
joint venture seeking to be awarded a publically bid construction contract.
   (f)    "Construction contract" means any publically bid construction
contract for the construction, rehabilitation, alteration, conversion,
extension or repair of buildings, streets or other improvements to real
property.
      (Ord. 2006-49. Passed 11-15-06.)
153.02 CONTRACT COMPLIANCE.
   All public contracts awarded by Village Council after public bidding shall
be required to comply with the provisions of Chapter
153  of the Woodmere Administrative Code as it relates to the Equal Employment
Opportunity Clause contained within this chapter.
(Ord. 2006-49. Passed 11-15-06.)
153.03 EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY CLAUSE.
   All public contracts hereinafter entered into by the Village shall
incorporate an Equal Employment Opportunity Clause, which shall read as
follows:
   (a)    The contractor shall not discriminate against any employee or
applicant for employment because of race, religion, color, sex or national
origin. The contractor shall take affirmative action to insure that applicants
are employed, and that employees are treated during employment, without regard
to their race, religion, color, sex or national origin.
As used herein the word "treated" means and includes without limitation, the
following: recruited, whether by advertising or other means; compensated,
whether in the form of rates of pay, or other forms of compensation; selected
for training, including apprenticeship; promoted; upgraded; demoted;
downgraded; transferred; laid off, and terminated. The contractor agrees to and
shall post in conspicuous places, available to employees and applicants for
employment, notices to be provided by the contracting officers setting forth
the provisions of this nondiscrimination clause.
   (b)    The contractor shall, in all solicitations or advertisements for
employees placed by or on behalf of the contractor, state that all qualified
applicants will receive consideration for employment without regard to race,
religion, color, sex or national origin.
   (c)    The contractor shall post and distribute to each labor union or
representative of workers with which he has a collective bargaining agreement
or other contract or understanding, notice of the contractor’s commitment to
the equal employment opportunity.
   (d)    The contractor shall furnish all information and reports required by
the Mayor and Village Council pursuant to Sections
153.01  to
153.07  inclusive, and shall permit access to books, records and accounts kept
by the contracting agency as may be requested by the Mayor or Village Council
for purposes of investigation to ascertain compliance with the Equal Employment
Opportunity Clause.
   (e)    The contractor shall take such action with respect to any
subcontractor as the Village may direct as a means of enforcing the provisions
of subsections (a) through (h) hereof, including penalties and sanctions for
noncompliance. However, in the event the contractor becomes involved in or is
threatened with litigation as the result of such direction by the Village, the
Village may enter into such litigation as is necessary to protect the interests
of the Village and to effectuate the Village's Equal Employment Opportunity
Program and in the case of contracts receiving Federal assistance, the
contractor or the Village may request the United States to enter into such
litigation to protect the interest of the United States.
   (f)    The contractor shall file and shall cause his subcontractors, if any,
to file compliance reports with the Village if requested by the Mayor and/or
the Village Council in the form and to the extent consistent with State and
Federal law. Compliance reports filed at such times as directed shall contain
information as to the employment practices, policies, programs and statistics
of the contractor and his subcontractors.
   (g)    The contractor shall include the provisions of subsections (a)
through (h) hereof, of this Equal Employment Opportunity Clause in every
subcontract or purchase order so that such provisions will be binding upon each
subcontractor or vendor.
   (h)    Refusal by the contractor or subcontractor to comply with any portion
of this program as herein stated and described will subject the offending party
to any or all of the following penalties:
      (1)    Withholding of all future payments under the involved publically
bid construction contract to the contractor in violation until it is determined
that the contractor or subcontractor is in compliance with the provisions of
the contract.
      (2)    Refusal of all future bids for any publically bid construction
contract with the Village or any of its departments or divisions until such
time as the contractor or subcontractor demonstrates that he has established
and shall carry out the policies of the program as herein outlined;
      (3)    Cancellation of the publically bid construction contract and
declaration of forfeiture of the performance bond.
         (Ord. 2006-49. Passed 11-15-06.)
153.04 CONTRACT COMPLIANCE REQUIREMENTS.
   All notices to prospective bidders published on behalf of the Village shall
include as a part of the contract specifications the condition that all bidders
shall be required to comply with the Woodmere Equal Employment Opportunity
Program, Chapter
153 , Woodmere Village Code.
(Ord. 2006-49. Passed 11-15-06.)
153.05 INTERGOVERNMENTAL COOPERATION.
   In the event specific discriminatory practices are found to exist in the
administration and enforcement of Sections
153.01  to
153.07  inclusive, in addition to the sanctions that may be imposed as provided
for by the terms of the contract, the Village shall forward all pertinent
information to the appropriate Federal and State agencies.
(Ord. 2006-49. Passed 11-15-06.)
153.06 SEVERABILITY.
   Sections
153.01  to
153.07  inclusive, and each part of such sections are hereby declared to be
independent sections and parts of sections and not withstanding any other
evidence of legislative intent, it is hereby declared to be the controlling
legislative intent that if any provision of such sections, or the application
thereof to any person or circumstances, is held invalid, the remaining sections
or parts of sections, and the application of such provision to any person or
circumstances, other than those as to which it is held invalid, shall not be
affected thereby, and it is hereby declared that the provisions of this chapter
would have been passed independently of such section, sections or part of a
section so held to be invalid.
(Ord. 2006-49. Passed 11-15-06.)
153.07 CIVIL RIGHTS COMPLIANCE.
   All complaints concerning potential violations of civil rights brought by
individuals pursuant to the award and performance of a publically bid
construction contract, as defined herein, shall be reviewed by the Mayor and
Village Council and, if not resolved, will be directed to forward the complaint
to the Ohio Civil Rights Commission or Office of Federal Contract Compliance.
(Ord. 2006-49. Passed 11-15-06.)
